channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What’s in a Word? A Chinese Dictionary Updates
item.description: The revised edition of the Standard Dictionary of Modern Chinese has just been released, and with it, more than 100 new terms — many slang or online neologisms — have been granted admission into the august realm of official Chinese lexicons.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Dictionary of Modern Standard Chinese, Third Edition.

item.title: Germany Steps Up Its Response to Global Security Crises
item.description: The country’s top politicians on Sunday approved the delivery of thousands of machine guns and hand grenades, as well as hundreds of antitank missiles, to Kurdish forces battling Islamic militants in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Agiripalli Journal: Redrawing a State in India Drives Land Prices to the Sky
item.description: In the newly divided state of Andhra Pradesh, real estate speculation has overtaken villages that may become part of a sprawling new capital.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmland along a corridor of the recently divided state of Andhra Pradesh has been bought up by speculators hoping to profit from the creation of a new capital.

item.title: Ukrainian Woman, Held Up to Public Abuse, Is Released
item.description: Irina Dovgan was wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and forced to stand on a sidewalk while holding a sign that read “She kills our children,” as passers-by slapped, kicked and spit on her.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Accused of spying, Irina Dovgan was wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and forced to endure public beatings and other abuse.

item.title: P.R. Firm for Putin’s Russia Now Walking a Fine Line
item.description: Ketchum’s staff members who provide public relations advice to Russia must avoid being seen as defending acts contrary to American interests while still providing some luster for a lucrative client.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Ketchum helped Vladimir V. Putin be selected as Time’s Person of the Year in 2007.

item.title: Lifting the Soul, and the Spanish Economy, Too
item.description: Despite the sagging Spanish economy — or perhaps because of it — the pilgrimage to the shrine of St. James in northwestern Galicia has become a booming part of modern Spain’s tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: U.S. and Iran Unlikely Allies in Iraq Battle
item.description: The fight for Amerli appeared to mark the first time American warplanes and militias backed by Iran were working with a common purpose on the battlefield against militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A Shiite militiaman in the Shiite Turkmen town of Amerli on Sunday after troops broke a six-week siege by ISIS with the help of American airstrikes.

item.title: Pakistani Army Calls for Calm After Protest Turns Deadly
item.description: At least three people died in clashes with the police when demonstrators, calling for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif’s resignation, marched toward his official residence.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A protester in Islamabad, Pakistan, threw a tear-gas shell back toward the police on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Set to Ratify Pledge on Joint Defense in Case of Major Cyberattack
item.description: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the NATO secretary general, said the pact was a start, “but I cannot tell you it is a complete strategy.

item.title: Libyans Overrun Compound Abandoned by U.S. Embassy in Tripoli
item.description: A video circulating online Sunday showed gleeful trespassers diving off a balcony into a pool in the residential compound abandoned by the American Embassy when it pulled out of Tripoli in July.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: 12 Are Killed as Militants Attack Prison in Somalia
item.description: At least 12 people were killed, including seven attackers, in what officials said was an attempt by the Shabab group to free fellow militants.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolled a security compound near the site of a prison attack on Sunday in Mogadishu.

item.title: Anti-Euro Party Wins Its First Seats in a German State Legislature
item.description: The party, Alternative for Germany, wants the country to stop using the euro as its currency, won seats in the Saxony state legislature.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: News Analysis: East Meets West to Fill European Post, and It’s Harder to Tell Them Apart
item.description: The election of Prime Minister Donald Tusk to lead the European Council may be an acknowledgment of Poland’s rising profile.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland, a rising nation, will lead the European Council.

item.title: Israel Claims Nearly 1,000 Acres of West Bank Land Near Bethlehem
item.description: The move could herald significant Israeli construction in the area — defying Palestinian demands for a halt in settlement expansion and challenging world opinion.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Residents of a Jewish settlement known as Gvaot near Bethlehem, where Israel laid claim to nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land.

item.title: Affiliate of Al Qaeda Confirms Capture of U.N. Peacekeepers in Syria
item.description: The Nusra Front, the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda, said it had seized more than 40 peacekeepers because the United Nations failed to help the people of Syria during the country’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier near the Quneitra crossing in the Golan Heights on Sunday in the area where the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda captured more than two dozen United Nations peacekeepers.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Arm Ukraine or Surrender
item.description: The West must back Kiev militarily or back down from Russia.
item.dc:creator: By BEN JUDAH

item.title: International Education: Illinois Revoked Job Offer After Professor Criticized Israel
item.description: Thousands of scholars and others are objecting after the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign revoked the offer following Twitter posts about Israel.
item.dc:creator: By SYDNI DUNN | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION

item.title: Putin Urges ‘Statehood’ Talks for Eastern Ukraine
item.description: In an interview Sunday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia veered between veiled threats and demands that the Ukraine government negotiate directly with separatists.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: In St. Petersburg, Russia, cutting boards displayed likenesses of President Vladimir V. Putin. On Sunday, Mr. Putin veered between veiled threats and demands for negotiations to resolve the conflict in Ukraine.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Trade Fire With Troops From U.N.
item.description: Gunfire broke out on Saturday between United Nations peacekeepers in southern Syria and the Islamist rebels who had been surrounding their base near the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: China Restricts Voting Reforms for Hong Kong
item.description: China’s legislature laid down strict limits to proposed voting reforms in Hong Kong, drawing battle lines in what could be a deepening confrontation over the future of the city and of China.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Protesters switched on their cellphones at a rally in Hong Kong on Sunday night after China curbed election reforms in the city.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: On Hong Kong, Democracy and Protecting the Rich
item.description: In an unusual theoretical leap, a leading Chinese academic said democracy in Hong Kong must be limited in order to protect the interests of its capitalist class.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Wang Zhenmin, dean of the Tsinghua University School of Law in Beijing.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Militants Besieging Turkmen in Iraq
item.description: American planes struck the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and dropped food, water and aid near the northern town of Amerli.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Ukraine President Says Europe’s Security Depends on Stopping Russia
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine won no pledges of military assistance from the European Union, but his warnings helped set the stage for a new round of sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian militiamen secured an area on the outskirts of Mariupol, where a Russian-backed assault was expected.

item.title: Facing Hard-Liners and Sanctions, Iran’s Leader Toughens Talk
item.description: In the second year of Hassan Rouhani’s presidency, he has struck a new tone, echoing the longstanding Iranian view that the United States can never be trusted.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani called the United States on Saturday the biggest obstacle to finding agreement on nuclear talks after it imposed new sanctions on Iran.

item.title: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Korea’s Leader in an Unflattering Light
item.description: The artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at an elite he considers responsible for a deadly ferry disaster, and has faced censorship he likens to his treatment during years of dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Hong Sung-dam with a replica of “Sewol Owol,” which was pulled from the Gwangju Beinnale for its parodies of the president.
